before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"53qep","text":"- install your zooscan on a perfectly straight and stable lab bench","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cvvru","text":"- install the associated software (zooprocess, vuescan... etc): https://sites.google.com/view/piqv/zooprocess-uvpapp?authuser=0","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":64,"length":63}],"data":{}},{"key":"3tq40","text":"- collect a plankton sample using a net and use logsheets to record all the metadata necessary to trace your sample","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"t2f1","text":"- remove seawater and fixative from the sample","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"B18C8F4937CB11ECBADC0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://sites.google.com/view/piqv/zooprocess-uvpapp?authuser=0"}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"2hin3","text":"The ZooScan (HYDROPTIC Inc.) is an imaging system for the measurement and classification of organisms and particles (150 µm to 5 cm) present in a liquid. steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"cjao2","text":"This protocol applies for the Zooprocess 7.27 version and above. The images are issued from versions up to 8.12.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cp6gj","text":"DO UPGRADE Zooprocess as often as it is updated on the PIQv website.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":55,"length":12}],"data":{}},{"key":"bbimf","text":"The PIQv would assist you only if you use the latest available update of Zooprocess.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1lspm","text":"This protocols does not describe the installation of the Zooscan software and drivers on your computer.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bu7g3","text":"More ddocumentation available on the PIQv website.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":37,"length":12}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2FDB3747CFB111ECA02B0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://sites.google.com/view/piqv"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8D841200E2BA11ECBFC2F38E23E206F5","url":"http://piqv.imev-mer.fr"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9pa2q","text":"This working protocol might be adjusted by users according to their experience and needs in order to take advantage of the tools provided by the application. We anyhow recommend to always keep the default settings offered by Zooprocess.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":158,"length":77}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ehhl9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"17n34","text":"The typical analysis sequence is as follow:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vnpn","text":"Fill in Sample metadata (as many sample as useful, can be done at sea...)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3cb2c","text":"SCAN and CONVERT a Background (on a daily base)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8k9a","text":"SCAN a Sample (one or several in a raw)","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4tm82","text":"CONVERT \u0026 PROCESS scanned SAMPLES in batch mode","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5btf8","text":"CHECK the process using segmented images","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ovuj","text":"SEPARATION of touching objects on selected vignettes","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bqjq0","text":"        - On vignettes (best option)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3h36k","text":"        - On global image, either B\u0026W or in grey level (old option)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5eri9","text":"PROCESS image again to include separation mask and get a better final dataset","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e1lbn","text":"IMPORT in Ecotaxa to predict identification and manually validate or correct the prediction made by the application.","type":"unordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dc24r","text":"The background image is a “blank” image that will be used during the image analysis process. It should be made before the samples are scanned and using the same parameters than for the scan of the samples. You have to scan a minimum of two background images (just follow the steps!) that will be combined in a unique “blank” image. You will do it at the beginning of every scanning session when you turn on your ZooScan, so usually every morning before the first sample. {"blocks":[{"key":"1t1qt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a503h","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bjieo","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ol8v","text":"The sample is sieved under the extractor hood to remove the preservative and the sea water. You can keep it to re-fill the sample afterwards. ","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"n3nv","text":"","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qr39","text":"For a mesh size net of 200 µm or less, in order to prevent the underestimation of large and rare organisms, the sample is sieved through a 1000 µm mesh and 100 µm mesh to get 2 size fractions.","type":"align-left","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4plt","text":"The two fractions are then splited with a motoda box before scanning to obtain a proper number of objects. By experience we scan 500-1000 objects for the large fraction that we recommend to name \"d1\" and 1000-2000 objects for the the lower fraction that we recommend to name \"d2\". These numbers can be adapted according to user experience and care. The number of touching organisms must be as limited as possible to avoid spending much time to later separate them from the images.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":169,"length":30},{"style":"bold","offset":249,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3mldm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1j4dg","text":"For \u003e 200 µm mesh size net, the fractions d1 and d2 are not necessary. The entire sample is directly splited with the motoda box and he fraction ID for scan is \"tot\". In this case, the proper number of ojects is 1000 to 2000 and replicates can be done if wanted.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7kd2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a6eqk","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9qu3h","text":"We describe below the general procedure in use at the Plateforme d’Imagerie Quantitative de Villefranche-sur-Mer for 200 µm mesh size nets.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":117,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"318h7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"495mk","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ajq2v","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6rl51","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"b07jf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"safety","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":213,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":213,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"7unek","text":"For safety reasons, we never poor directly the samples containing formalin on the Zooscan tray but we previously remove the seawater and formalin from the sample and use filtered seawater (or fresh water) instead.","type":"align-justify"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":174,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":174,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"779vn","text":"Please do consider that the FORMALIN is a carcinogen and mutagen product. Apply all necessary safety procedure to avoid any risk when you remove the formalin from the sample:","type":"align-justify"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":25,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":25,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"2fuo7","text":"work in a extractor hood ","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":32,"offset":0,"style":"bold"},{"length":32,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"85ita","text":"use gloves, glasses and lab coat","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"36BE22A037C811EC9B913B6FA775D975","height":296.32727272727266,"id":257803,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":293,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"378rs","text":"Procedure to prepare a sample collected using a WP2 net (200 µm) : a) removal of the seawater and formalin, b) the sample is optionally sieved in two fractions, c) each of them is optionalloy splited in order to get convenient numbers of organisms and d) scan of both fractions (“d1” and “d2”)","type":"align-center"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52pbnzq7.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52mbnzq7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52nbnzq7.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52kbnzq7.webp","width":580}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8eqbd","text":"We use only MOTODA splitting system at PIQv. Our recommendation are thus applicable for this system.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e5bqc","text":"You can control that it is usefull to sieve the sample in two size fractions by comparing the splitting ratio necessary to obtain a good image or a correct quantity of organisms for the two fractions.","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1u2bc","text":"In order to avoid mistakes during the splitting procedure using the Motoda box, we recommend to keep all successive remaining fractions in pre-labelled jars (1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16….).","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"30qqv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7gl7q","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"16qbp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6nabu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9o7su","text":"The METADATA must be previously filled (see chapter 4)","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3olnp","text":"The BACKGROUND must be scanned (see chapter 6)","type":"unordered-list-item"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6kja3","text":"Pour some water (freshwater or filtered seawater) on the scanning tray until the glass is totally covered (don’t cover the edges of the frame at this step as the addition of the sample will then cover the edge). In order to prevent condensation and bubbles to appear on the ZooScan tray (because of the differents temperatures between the working room and the water in the pipes), we recommend to anticipate your water usage and store few liters of water in the same room than the instrument.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"trf5","text":"Place the frame. The frame size (NARROW or LARGE) depends on your choices at chapter 2 \"Create new project\". Check that the frame is well placed, touching the recommended and tagged corners of the scanning tray as for the scan of the background (see chapter 7).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dphtg","text":"Clean water droplets or marks on the frame and remove the dirtiness in you water with pipette and the cactus sticks.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"f7ci0","text":"Pour the sample from the last fraction of the Motoda box.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fvtr5","text":"Add water (if necessary) until all the edges of the frame are covered as for the background. If you pour too much water, the floating organisms will be out of focus. You thus have to struggle between : enough water to cover the edges and an insuficiant level to avoid out of focus organisms.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dui74","text":"Allow 15-20 minutes to separate touching organisms with the cactus sticks. No organisms on the edge and along the edge! Pay attention to the separation of the objects from each other. Make a compromise between the time spent for this task and the quality of the image. After the process of the image, you can separate touching objects on the final image with the separation tool (see chapter 11) in Zooprocess but you may loose details on the organisms and they may be truncated.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4tuig","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8s6fa","text":"You can accelerate the separation of organisms by pouring the sample homogeneously on the tray and by pouring the extra water on conglomerated organisms of the tray to “dissolve” them.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3o1kv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9b7i0","text":"Place the larger individuals in the center of the tray because the image will be cropped on the edges of the frame. If some organisms are floating, try to sink them by little pushes with the cactus sticks (the size measurements of floating organisms are biased, and their image captions are blurred). If they do not sink and are very few, the best option is to move them apart of the image (e.g. placing them on the edge of the frame). This step is critical to have good data quality.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3p8dq","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ajlar","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"20dod","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"bepca","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"6DE66C40D2D411EC8A22017EC2452FC2","height":343.10545454545445,"id":257807,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"46v43","text":"Example of \"d1\" scan (large fraction \u003e 1000µm)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52tbnzq7.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52rbnzq7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52sbnzq7.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52qbnzq7.webp","width":537.6296296296296}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"51431D70D2D611EC8A22017EC2452FC2","height":339.08545454545447,"id":257811,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1oib8","text":"Example of \"d2\" scan (100 - 1000µm)","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"image.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52xbnzq7.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52vbnzq7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52wbnzq7.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52ubnzq7.webp","width":531.3304843304843}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"arnr4","text":"Check that there is no condensation on the glass of the ZooScan cover.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5d8gl","text":"Launch Zooprocess, select your project and click on the option: “SCAN sample with Zooscan (for archive, no process)”.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"39s19","text":"Select the sample name. Then, follow the instructions that pop up on the screen (Zooprocess Instructions window). In Zooprocess, select the proper fraction name “d1”, “d2”, “tot” or user defined according to the fraction (100µm\u003c”d2”\u003c1000µm, d1 \u003e 1000µm, “tot” if no sieving) when asked.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9e2ao","text":"Follow carefully the instructions in the Zooprocess windows to start the scan of the sample (one scan only). Do not forget to press OK in Zooprocess after pressing SCAN in Vuescan. Do not touch any key of the keyboard during the scan ! Do not make any vibration on the Zooscan that may perturbate the water surface on the tray! For Biotom, v1 and v2 Zooscan versions : do not forget to turn on the green light of the Zooscan before launching the scan in Vuescan. WAIT 30 seconds between the preview and the actual scan. v3: select the UPPER light!","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cqmum","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bd5vv","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"hpdp","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":145,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"2nfi4","text":"Three files will be created in the “_raw” folder of the project. The filename is composed of the sample name plus the fraction name (sample_d1) :","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":149,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"8mr2l","text":"The TIF image (16 bits) will be processed later when using ”CONVERT \u0026 PROCESS Images and organisms in batch mode” option in the Zooprocess main menu.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":310,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"2e5v3","text":"The META file gives information on the sampling method (e.g., sampling site net dimensions, tow, volume) and on the sample preparation for the Zooscan (e.g., pre-filtering and subsampling ratio). It summarizes the information contained in the sample and scan tables (*.csv) from the meta folder of the project.","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":69,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"3u4c9","text":"The LOG file records information on the scanning method (parameters).","type":"ordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"a38qt","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":94,"offset":0,"style":"align-left"}],"key":"5f78e","text":"An additional scan_header.csv file records all scanning information in the Zooscan_meta folder","type":"unordered-list-item"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dqi4t","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cg06m","text":"   ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"10br4","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"42610D4037F311EC9B913B6FA775D975","height":215,"id":257815,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":15,"offset":0,"style":"italic"}],"key":"dd2gl","text":"In your folders","type":"align-center"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"do.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h523bnzq7.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52zbnzq7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h522bnzq7.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h52ybnzq7.webp","width":326},"mutability":"","type":"image"}}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dejtb","text":"Remove and rinse the transparent frame with a wash squeeze bottle above the scanning tray to recover all specimens that may be stuck on it.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b1gur","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fjbnf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"dp9so","text":"Remove the sample from the tray: lift the ZooScan gently and maintain it (i.e., always hold the tray when you lift it to remove the water or it could fall). ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"24s0u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4tcmv","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"aglno","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"49C45D10D2D711EC8A22017EC2452FC2","height":198.7412935323383,"id":257819,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"image/png","original_name":"nettoyage zooscan.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h527bnzq7.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h525bnzq7.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h526bnzq7.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/h524bnzq7.webp","width":264.5496688741722}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cbpa7","text":"Clean the tray with a wash squeeze bottle of freshwater or filtered seawater to avoid contamination between the differents samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8as02","text":"Prepare another sample or clean and DRY the scanning tray using fresh water if you end a scanning session.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.section: CONVERT AND PROCESS IMAGES AND ORGANISMS IN BATCH MODE
steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"a8g2l","text":"The image process can be performed just after the scan if you use a powerful computer or during night or lunch time.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"57nbb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3m50b","text":"It is very important to process the scanned images as soon as possible after their acquisition or at least every day. The process permits to rapidly check (see chapter 11) that the background and the samples have been correctly acquired.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":237}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6lek4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6hngo","text":"Start Zooprocess if necessary or click once on the Z icon if Zooprocess is already opened and select the tool “CONVERT \u0026 PROCESS scanned SAMPLES in batch mode” :","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8rsb2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8m374","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1p49c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eks56","text":"Then, select “Convert AND Process Image AND particles (images in RAW folder)”. information:","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"80ks2","text":"","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":1,"offset":0}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3tscf","text":"  ","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"d8p92","text":"The resulting files are saved in the _work and Pid_results folders.","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8u6da","text":"","type":"align-left"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"98p7e","text":"The .pid file is a single file that concatenates the log.txt, the meta.txt, the processing functions applied and the meas.txt (table containing all objects (rows) and their measurements (columns)). The measurements that might be utilized to compute the size for the data analysis are Area, Major and Minor (major and minor axes of an ellipse that have the same area of the object measured). Other measurements correspond to variables of shape and texture used for automatic recognition, and of position in the tray. warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"4u7r1","text":"For safety reasons, we never poor directly the samples containing formalin on the Zooscan tray but we previously remove the seawater and formalin from the sample and use filtered seawater (or fresh water) instead.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"align-left","offset":0,"length":213}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1pjum","text":"Please do consider that the FORMALIN is a carcinogen and mutagen product.
